An objective measure for the visual fidelity of virtual reality and the risks of falls in a virtual environment

  • R. J. Menzies1,
  • S. J. Rogers1,
  • A. M. Phillips1,
  • E. Chiarovano2,
  • C. de Waele2,
  • F. A. J. Verstraten1 &
  • H. MacDougall1 

Virtual Reality volume 20, pages173–181(2016)Cite this article

  • 1926 Accesses

  • 10 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Despite decades of development of virtual reality (VR) devices and VR’s recent renaissance, it has been difficult to measure these devices’ effectiveness in immersing the observer. Previously, VR devices have been evaluated using subjective measures of presence, but in this paper, we suggest that postural stability can be used to objectively assess visual fidelity of VR headsets. We validated this measure by testing known differences between the devices. This study also aimed to determine the stability of healthy participants, while in a stable virtual world, compared to eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions and therefore provide a standard of safety requirements for future experimentation. Participants’ ability to maintain a stable centre of pressure was measured using a Wii Balance Board, covered by a foam pad. Stability in eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions was compared with: (1) an iPod Touch in a simple Google cardboard style headset, (2) the Oculus Rift Development Kits (DK) DK1, DK2, with and without the tracking of linear head movements, and (3) the Samsung Gear VR. With a stable VR visual stimulus, the eyes-open condition allowed for significantly greater postural stability than the other conditions, which supports the validity of posturography as a measure of visual fidelity. Further, the iPod Touch, with its narrow field of view and rudimentary software, was significantly less effective at destabilising participants with visual perturbations than the other headsets, with their wider field of view and time warping. Unexpected results are discussed with respect to the possible limitations of the experimental design.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) is the presentation of an artificial environment that can sense the participant’s position and actions and replace or augment components of their sensory feedback, evoking a feeling of being present in the virtual world (Sherman and Craig 2002). Head-mounted displays, referred to as headsets throughout this paper, achieve a participant-centric perspective, large field of view (FOV) and stereoscopic visual field that is continuously modified by head position and rotation (Czernuszenko et al. 1997). Images move across the display screens in the opposite direction to head movement and are synchronised to head velocity, creating a visual illusion of real objects fixed relative to the world. The effectiveness of VR devices depends on FOV, display resolution, tracking motion-to-photon latency, and frames per second, all of which have recently been significantly improved with advances in computer algorithms and processing speed. While VR technology was originally intended for research and military applications, recent development has been focused on its entertainment potential (Macedonia and Rosenbloom 2001). As VR is used more extensively in research and entertainment, valid evaluations of its quality are required.

Postural stability is the ability to maintain balance while standing upright and is dependent on afferent input from the visual, somatosensory and vestibular systems (Vouriot et al. 2004). Variations in centre of pressure (COP) are commonly used as the posturographic measure of postural stability (Duarte and Freitas 2010). COP can be measured using force plates through the analysis of the distribution of vertical force across their surface (Goble et al. 2014). Postural sway is the resultant measure of postural stability, defined as the oscillations of the COP around a defined equilibrium point or centre (Riemann et al. 1999). In particular, the Wii Balance Board (WBB, Nintendo, Kyoto, Japan) has been validated as an inexpensive yet reliable posturography device for the measurement of sway through comparison with commercially available force plates, including the Equitest (Clark et al. 2010). Somatosensory input is an important contributor to balance, and therefore, the impairment of this system results in greater reliance on visual and vestibular systems (Elliot et al. 1995). Disruption of somatosensory input from the feet and ankles, which provides information about spatial position and stability, can be achieved by placing a foam pad (e.g. the Airex Balance Pad) over the WBB during testing (Chiarovano et al. 2015).

Instability is commonly induced using visual perturbations (Simoneau et al. 1999). The visual system’s contribution to balance can be manipulated by presenting a moving stimulus to the participant and measuring resultant changes in postural stability with a force plate (Blanks et al. 1996). However, these studies have found that it is difficult to encompass the entire field of view using large computer monitors, and visual information beyond the boundaries of the screen provides stability cues. VR headsets address this limitation by obscuring unwanted additional visual cues. Chiarovano et al. (2015) used a moving visual scene within a VR headset to demonstrate the importance of somatosensory cues to maintain stability. They found that when the visual system was perturbed as participants stood on a WBB plus foam pad (WBB+f), they had significantly greater postural instability and suggested this was the result of their inability to interpret the visual stimuli as false information.

As it is used throughout this paper, presence is defined as the experience of being in a virtual world and responding to virtual stimuli as if they were real (Slater 1999). Research using VR that requires its findings be translatable to real world behaviour therefore need to invoke a strong sense of presence in their participants. Presence is currently measured mainly through questionnaires, where each question aims to probe a different aspect of the participant’s subjective experience (Takatalo et al. 2008; Usoh et al. 2000; Slater 1999). However, subjective measures, including questionnaires, are limited (Slater et al. 2009). Questionnaires have been shown to be unstable and vary significantly with experimental conditions outside the VR, for example, questions regarding interest in the stimulus affect evaluations of presence (Freeman et al. 1999). Presence questionnaires may also suffer from methodological circularity, where questions asked about presence could create and measure a post hoc experience that is not reflective of participants’ actual feelings when in the virtual environment (Slater et al. 2009). This has led to the development of less subjective evaluations, including physiological and behavioural tests of presence that are based on the comparison of participant reactions to stimuli in VR and real world (Slater et al. 2009). Distinct from presence, immersion is commonly defined as the objective measure of how well the VR display matches the real world (Slater 1999). Components of immersion, which include FOV, frame rate and head tracking, are correlated with subjective feelings of presence reported by participants (Sanchez-Vives and Slater 2005). This suggests that, holding all other aspects of the virtual equal, participants’ feelings of presence, as measured here by postural stability, would vary with the VR headset used.

We define the visual fidelity of a VR device as a measure of how convincing the virtual environment is and its resultant ability to induce feelings of presence. As VR has potential applications in many different fields, it is important for the VR to have a high visual fidelity. A higher visual fidelity implies the ability to provide visual feedback that is more useful for stability during the presentation of a stable stimulus, and more destabilising when the visual stimulus is inconsistent with vestibular input. We therefore propose that postural stability can be used as an objective behavioural measure of the visual fidelity of VR headsets by comparing the postural responses induced by different visual conditions. Therefore, the aim of this study was to validate this measure based on its ability to detect the differences between VR conditions and eyes open and eyes closed. As the presence or absence of vision has been found to reliably affect postural stability (Diener et al. 1984; Hytönen et al. 1993; Palus et al. 1984; Prieto et al. 1996), we used eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions to serve as standards for comparison for reliable or impaired visual information, respectively. We hypothesised that our measure of postural stability would corroborate the well known fact that postural stability is better with eyes open than eyes closed. We also hypothesised that it would find greater visual fidelity, as measured by postural stability, in more immersive headsets and therefore distinguish between these devices. It is important to establish the risk of falls associated with standing in a stable virtual world as such virtual environments are expected to be important research tools. We therefore also compared VR headsets presenting stable stimuli with eyes open and eyes closed to determine the safety requirements for subsequent experiments using VR.

Method

Participants and design

This study was approved by the University of Sydney Human Ethics Committee—Protocol Number 2015/279. All participants were associated with the University of Sydney and had no record of vestibular or central pathologies. The sample was comprised of 17 (4 females) volunteer participants (Mean age = 29.8, minimum = 19, maximum = 72). During the trials, a safety rail was positioned around the participant and an experimenter was positioned behind them to prevent them from falling.

Materials

The visual stimulus was created in Unity 3D, a rendering software, and was consistent across all headsets. The virtual environment presented a head-centred 3D field of 1000 randomly distributed white discs (RGB levels from 0 to 255 were R: 255, G: 255, B: 255) of radius 10 cm and visual angle 0.28°–1.14° of the participant’s field of view. The discs were positioned between 10 and 20 m from the head centre on a blue background (R: 49, G: 77, B: 121). A screenshot of the virtual environment as rendered in each headset is shown in Fig. 1.

We define a stable visual field as one that reacts to changes in head position and rotation to provide a virtual environment analogous to the real world, while a moving visual field has additional perturbations. For each headset, there was one condition in which this virtual environment was stable, and four others where it was rotated at 20°/s around the Z = ±Y axes. These axes are defined according to convention in posturography research where positive X direction is forward, positive Y direction is left and positive Z direction is up (Niven et al. 1966). From the participant’s perspective, the dots appeared to move diagonally across the screen in the four diagonal directions: up-right, up-left, down-right or down-left. As an example, the down-right stimulus is represented within the headset in Fig. 2.

A 6 cm thick foam Airex Balance Pad was placed on the WBB, and participants stood on top of this to reduce somatosensory input during testing. The WBB+f was surrounded by a safety support frame, firmly fixed to the ground, with rails at the approximate hand height of the participant. This experimental set-up is shown in Fig. 2.

The VR headsets used included an Apple iPod Touch 5th Generation 16 GB (model MGG82ZP/A) in a ColorCross housing (iPod + CC), and three Oculus Rift devices: Development Kit 1 (DK1), DK2 and Samsung Gear VR. All of the headsets were capable of angular tracking, where the device responds to angular head rotation; however, only the DK2 was also capable of linear tracking, such that the device responds to head translation as well as angular rotation. The relevant properties of the different headsets are shown in Table 1. It is based on these properties, and the resultant immersiveness, that we distinguish between high- and low-quality headsets.

FOV is the visual angle through which the observable world that can be seen in the headset. Latency is defined as the delay between the device starting to render the visual field and the user viewing it (Kruijff et al. 2010). The refresh rate value is the number of frames shown on the visual display per second (Sontisirki 2014). Persistence is a measure of how long the image is displayed for each frame before a new image is rendered. Full persistence means the image stays on the screen until the new image appears, while low persistence means the image disappears shortly after it is seen, leaving a subliminal interval with no image. Time warp is a software technique which renders a 3D model into a 2D image, a relatively slow, computationally demanding process, and translates it to compensate for changes in angular head position which occurs while rendering the 3D scene (Mark et al. 1997). Predictive head tracking estimates head orientation at frame presentation time by integrating the angular velocity and acceleration at frame rendering time (LaValle et al. 2014). Although the DK1 and DK2 have a higher latency than the Gear VR or iPod, the use of time warping and predictive head tracking compensate for this difference. Based on its low FOV and lack of time warping, the iPod is considered to be of lower quality than the other headsets.

Procedure

Participants were fully briefed, and consent was obtained from each participant prior to commencing the study. Participants were tested using the iPod + CC, the DK1, the DK2, the DK2 with linear tracking implemented (DK2L) and the Gear VR. The order of the headsets, eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions was randomised amongst the participants, as was the order of stimuli, stable and the four perturbed conditions, within each headset. The total experiment was approximately 30 min.

Participants stood on the WBB+f without shoes and feet together. They completed trials with eyes open, eyes closed and in each of the five headsets. Each trial lasted 20 s or until participants lost their balance and/or required assistance. If the participant touched the support frame’s rail, or the experimenter had to intervene to prevent the participant falling backwards, the trial was recorded as a fall. Participants completed one trial with a stable VR stimulus for each visual condition, and four trials with the stimulus rotating in each of four diagonal directions for each headset.

Postural stability in the different visual conditions was compared using their stability scores as described by Chiarovano et al. (2015). This measure is based on mean distance of the participant’s COP from equilibrium and their limit of stability (LOS). LOS is defined as the point on the ground directly below the centre of mass (COM), which is assumed to be positioned at 55 % of the participant’s height (Winter 2004), when the body is leaning at an angle of 6.25° (Nashner et al. 1982). This is all summarised in Fig. 3 in the context of this experiment. The WBB measures the force applied at each of its four corners to calculate the participants’ COP, and this is then smoothed with a low-pass filter. The iOS BalanceRite application (Chiarovano et al. 2015) receives the data over Bluetooth at a 100 Hz sampling rate from the WBB and calculates the displacement of the COP from their initial centre at each time point (graphical representation of displacement from equilibrium shown in Fig. 4). The distance between the centre and COP relative to the distance between the centre and LOS produces a percentage at each time point. If the participants’ COP is over the centre, this percentage is equal to 100 at that time point, while it is 0 if COP is at the LOS. If the COP exceeds the LOS, the participant will generally step off the board or require assistance to remain upright, both of which are regarded as a fall. If a fall occurs, the percentage is equated to zero for all remaining time points. These percentages are summed and finally divided by the number of samples in a trial to produce the score.

Results

The results of comparing the average score for each headset and the eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions using a Wilcoxon signed-rank sum test are shown in Fig. 5. The eyes-open condition was found to be significantly more stable than the other conditions (p < 0.0001), while the eyes-closed condition was significantly less stable than the DK1 and iPod + CC (p < 0.02). Other comparisons were not significant.

The average scores for each headset in the perturbed condition were analysed using the Wilcoxon signed-rank sum test and shown in Fig. 6. The mean was calculated for all directions per participant per device, and the participant means were grouped together to compare devices. The iPod + CC was found to be significantly less destabilising than the other devices (p < 0.001), and the DK2 was significantly less destabilising than the DK2L (p < 0.04) and the DK1 (p < 0.04). Other comparisons were not significant.

The average number of falls was compared between the headsets, as seen in Fig. 7. The iPod + CC was found to have significantly fewer falls than the other headsets. No significant difference was found between the other headsets.

Discussion

The present study proposes an objective measure for comparing the visual fidelity of VR headsets. It was hypothesised that this measure would corroborate the differences between eyes-open and eyes-closed conditions and distinguish the high- from the low-quality headsets. As shown in Fig. 5, postural stability was significantly greater in the eyes-open condition than all the headsets and the eyes-closed condition. In addition, postural stability was significantly higher in the DK1 and iPod + CC than in the eyes-closed condition. No significant difference was found between the other headsets presenting a stable stimulus and eyes closed. This is surprising because the headsets varied in immersion, represented by their different properties (Table 1), but may be explained by limitations of our methodology. These headset properties may have been made more salient by improving stimulus presentation, for example, through the encouragement of exploration of the virtual environment. This should be investigated in future research.

An important implication of the result that each of the headsets facilitated either equivalent, or superior, postural stability compared to eyes closed is that it gives an indication of the risk associated with performing experiments in a stable VR environment. In particular, the risk of destablisation is equivalent to that for eyes closed, as is the likelihood and rate of falls, which depend on postural stability. Further, no falls were observed in any of the stable conditions, even with impaired somatosensory input. Therefore, in future experiments, the standards of safety for testing healthy participants using a stable virtual environment are determined by the requirements of testing with eyes closed. Most experiments using VR would not impair somatosensory input, and therefore, safety requirements would be minimal, as they are for eyes closed when standing on a stable surface. For example, the Romberg test, where participants stand with their feet together and eyes open or closed, requires no safety support except the supervision of the examiner (Khasnis and Gokula 2003). The results of this experiment therefore allow future studies using VR to justify their safety precautions when testing participants with or without reliable somatosensory input.

For the moving stimulus, it was hypothesised that the measure of postural stability would differentiate between the low- and high-quality headsets, where quality is representative of immersiveness. This finding was confirmed, as shown in Fig. 6. Participants were significantly more stable in the VR perturbations for the iPod + CC. This is likely because of its lack of time warping and smaller FOV (Table 1) which qualify it as a low-quality headset and might reduce participants’ conviction of the visual stimulus. The difference between low- and high-quality VR headsets was observed in the moving but not the stable stimulus conditions. A possible explanation for this could be that by moving the virtual world, the participants were provided with a clearer concept of a 3D environment, and this may have enhanced the visual fidelity of each headset and the ability to differentiate between headsets of different qualities.

Participants tended to keep their head and eyes directed straight ahead and did not explore the immersive field. This lack of exploratory behaviour might naturally impair the illusion of a virtual world which moves relative to head movement and produce a stimulus more similar to an image on a fixed computer screen. This would prevent participants from experiencing strong feelings of presence, thus reducing the stabilising effect of the VR stable condition and the destabilising effect of the VR moving condition. Future research could therefore encourage participants to engage with the VR environment before the experiment commences, for example, by instructing them to search for an object in their periphery. Alternatively, participants could be instructed to follow targets that move out of their field of view throughout the experiment. In order to observe these features in the environment, participants would have to move their head around the virtual environment, destabilising them and encouraging greater dependence on the visual cues and facilitating a better understanding of the response of the 3D virtual world in which they are situated. Another factor affecting the results may have been the intervals between trials. Longer intervals may have allowed participants to more effectively recover their balance, as occasionally falls were observed in stable conditions immediately after a perturbing stimulus trial.

It was only hypothesised that postural stability, as a measure of visual fidelity, would capture differences between headsets of low and high quality. However, we also found that in the moving stimulus condition, the DK2 was significantly less destabilising than both the DK2L and the DK1 (Fig. 6), suggesting this measure can capture more subtle differences between headsets. The comparison with the DK2L is straightforward given the only difference between these two conditions is that the DK2L employs linear tracking in addition to the angular tracking. A headset that can track linear position and reproduce these visual cues is likely to provide more compelling balance information. This can be explained by the important visual cues provided by linear movement of the head, such as parallax motion (Bronstein and Buckwell 1997), which is inevitable when the body sways. However, the comparison with the DK1 was unexpected. As the main difference between the DK1 and DK2 is a greater FOV, this result may be a further indication of the importance of FOV for constructing a convincing environment.

Given the surprising results of the stable conditions, with higher scores for the DK1 and iPod, the number of falls in the stable condition was compared between headsets. As shown in Fig. 7, the iPod + CC was found to have significantly fewer falls than the other headsets, but no significant difference was found between the other headsets. Further, there were no falls for any of the stable conditions, nor falls for eyes open and eyes closed, which was expected.

The present study validated postural stability as an objective, qualitative measure of visual fidelity. In the future, it could be used to place the different VR headsets on a continuum and thereby capture the differences in quality between consumer devices. In particular, instructing participants to move laterally might reveal differences between the DK2L with its linear tracking capability and other devices lacking that capability, thus revealing the importance of linear tracking. Other areas of potential research include the relative effects on stability of direction of movement (horizontal, vertical and diagonal axes) and whether stability is mediated by individual differences such as handedness and video gaming experience. A future study should also look to compare our objective measure of visual fidelity with participants’ subjective evaluation of presence measured by a questionnaire. Comparison of the properties of the headsets (Table 1) and their stability scores would also be informative for future research to determine which properties, individually as well as in combination, are the important contributors to visual fidelity.
